p: Swertia chirayita is a popular ancient herbal plant which became familiarized to Europe in 1839. The plant is familiar for its multiple names like Nidrari, Haima, Ramasenka, Kairata (in Sanskrit), Chiravata (in Urdu), Chireta (in Bengali) and Qasabuzzarirah (in Arabic and Farsi) [ 41]. The plant mainly matures at tall altitudes in sub-temperature regions specifically slopes of Himalayan shady places, typically between the altitudes of 1200–1500 m from Bhutan to Kashmir [ 12, 42]. The places, where the plant is also cultivated are middle part, Meghalaya and Khasi hills of India. The genus is well known in Chinese traditional medicinal practices and twenty of such species from the same genus were being implemented for treating hepatic, inflammatory and choleric diseases [ 21]. Total forty endangered species of Swertia chirayita have been identified in India and they are mostly annual or biennial herb [ 43, 44]. Such medicinal herb grows maximum up to 0.5–1.5 m. Leaves of such plant are lanceolate, has a cordate base, containing five to seven nerves, almost oppositely oriented and almost 4 cm length [ 45]. The root of such medicinal herb is simple, yellowish in colour, somewhat oblique, almost 7–8 cm long whereas flowers look small, numerous, tetramerous and green-yellowish in colour [ 46].
